Alright, that was the simple review, time for my detailed one. 
Ahem I'd recommend grabbing a snack. 

(This review is mainly for people looking to buy the game.)
(Some details are omitted for spoiler purposes)

Graphics: I personally adore the graphic style, it is not at all "realistic" if that is the style of games you're looking for. It's a game that has a "cartoony" vibe with dark undertones. Think, 2d platformer smashed with a 3d dungeon crawler then add some gore. It's a stylized look, as I'm sure you can tell from the pictures. There isn't much to say about the graphics besides they are awesome if you love tarot cards.

Gameplay: Personally I dont give a rats ass if the game is repetitive, if you dislike repetitive games DO NOT GET THIS GAME. I've seen reviews of people talking about how they HATE the gameplay loop. Allow me to describe the game loop to you quickly. 

Lamb (You) has a cult (Think animal crossing village), and to get materials, they need to leave the cult. Which is where the dungeon crawler comes in. 

You go through an area, get your materials, come back to the cult, build shit, then leave. 

Seems repetitive, which it is. However there are some things I glossed over like the fact you can leave the dungeon anytime (If you have the cloak for it, a cloak upgrade is basically when you defeat a big boss you get something to get a new cloak, and an ability of one of those cloaks is you can teleport out of the dungeon whenever you want with a short windup). So you're not "forced" to go through the full dungeon. Plus, I've actually seen people completely skip over the dungeon crawler portion, which I find kinda insane. The dungeon crawler is a key component of the game, but you CAN avoid it, HOWEVER it is SIGNIFICANTLY more difficult to deal with your cult.

 Basically what I'm stating here is: If you don't like dungeon crawlers this isn't the game for you, but if you love the game enough (stubborn enough) you could avoid that part of the game. You will be missing the story however so it's not recommended. 

Alright lets talk about the difficulty of the dungeon crawler itself now that everyone who hates dungeon crawlers has left. 

The difficulty of the dungeon crawler itself is player focused/skill. There are things that can assist, or make it more difficult for players either looking for a challenge or simplicity, which I will not get into much as that leads to spoilers. But lets simplify it, lets say you're just using vanilla lamb (basic/starter kit). Here's the basic dungeon rundown:

When you go into a dungeon, the dungeon will show multiple types of rooms. A dungeon run is called a CRUSADE. There's 14 total types of rooms. I would highly recommend searching â€œCult Of The Lamb: Level Typesâ€ if you're a visual learner. I'll list all the rooms you'll come across keeping one out for spoiler purposes. If not, I'll try to explain here. The brackets are the symbols you'll see

Normal fight (Sword Symbol), Hearts (Heart), Coins (Coin), Food (The Food of that Dungeon), Lumber (Chopped Wood), Stone (Rocks), Bones (Crossbones), Tarot (Card), Shop (Shop), Event (Question Mark), New follower (Stick Figure Kneeling, Holding Hands upward), Miniboss (Skull and Crossbones). 

Okay Now ill briefly explain what each room actually IS;

Normal Fight: I will come back to this one to not confuse you

Hearts: You get Health

Coins: You get Money

Food: You get Food for your Cult

Lumber: You get Wood for your Cult

Stone: You get Stone for your Cult

Bones: You get Bones for your Cult 

Tarot: You get an NPC that gives you a temporary bonus ability ONLY for that run

Shop: You can buy shit there. Do you not know what a store is? Touch grass.

Event: This one basically has a chance of a few different rooms and I will avoid stating because of spoilers.


New Follower: You get the CHANCE to free a NPC to join your cult

Miniboss: This one will ONLY EVER appear at the end of the dungeon run. It is exactly as it's said. It's a miniboss. 

Alright now you know what rooms are congrats. Let's go back to the Normal Fight room. You will ALWAYS start a Crusade in a Normal Fight Room. A normal fight room is basically where you go through multiple smaller rooms freeroam (you get a minimap) and you fight shit. Make sure you explore everywhere because most of the time you have the chance of running into a Tarot type room, or an NPC, or Treasure. What's Treasure? Treasure can vary. Coins, Materials, or Weapons to use in the dungeon. During the start of the Crusade when you enter the Normal Fight Room you will get 2 weapons. A physical one, and a ranged one, and yes you carry this weapon throughout your entire crusade.

If your fucking confused. Think of a Russian nesting doll. There are the General levels, which I mentioned. Then the Normal Fight Rooms.

Okay enough about the gameplay, if you really need to know more search up a video stupid. 

Audio: The audio is heavenly, you just gotta hear it for yourself. Sadly the person who made the original music passed away. RIP your music was beautiful. 

PC Requirements: It's pretty average. You don't need a super computer, but you still have a decent computer. The size is workable, there really isn't much to talk about here, idk what computer you have. Figure it out yourself.

Grind: There isn't a grind. UNLESS you care about achievements. If you do, Wellâ€¦ have fun. 

Story: I will not go into the story at all as this is mostly a spoiler free review. However, the story is good, and the Final Boss Fight is awesome. Highly recommended.

Game Time: It gets repetitive, the game will go as long as you can go. 

Price: For me it's highly worth the price, and if you don't think so, just wait for it to go on sale. It goes on sale very often. I bought it full price, with every possible DLC. (Jumping on Woolhaven the second its OFFICIALLY out).

Bugs: Very Minor Bugs, If you do find any, report to the discord. They deal with it pretty quickly.

For me? 10/10 I love being a psychopathic lamb that runs a cult.


Thanks for reading my essay of a review, and I hope it helps you decide if you would be interested in the game or not! (RIP to my fingers)

The combination of base-building, follower management, and dungeon combat makes the gameplay varied and deeply satisfying.

Meanwhile, the cult management adds layers of strategy â€” you feed your followers, assign tasks, and deal with moral choices that impact loyalty, keeping you invested in your little community.

The visuals and soundtrack are fantastic. The art style is adorable yet slightly sinister, giving the game a unique personality, while the music perfectly balances lighthearted charm and ominous undertones. There are also tons of secrets, upgrades, rituals, and collectibles that reward exploration and experimentation.

Replay value is high thanks to multiple dungeon paths, unique items, and the challenge of maintaining a happy, loyal cult. The game balances humor, strategy, and action in a way few games do, making each session feel fresh and engaging.

This game is almost entirely carried by it's aesthetic.

It is an isometric combat rogue-like mixed with a base builder, and it does all of those things at an alright level.

This game excels in nothing other than it's art direction, the combat gameplay is uninteresting. It's not very fun, challenging, or engaging in any way. I found most rooms you can just run through with ease leaving it feeling pretty bland (played on normal difficulty). However, the few times the game did present a challenge I found that the gameplay wasn't sufficient enough for it to feel anything other than unclear hitboxes. The game has a "pop-up" effect on all of it's characters, which often leads to combat in the game feeling very loose and makes it hard to discern where hitboxes are. For 90% of my playthrough this wasn't an issue because the gameplay is so bland and simple that it doesn't matter. But for the 10% of the game that was somewhat difficult, I often didn't feel "challenged" by the difficulty but more often just sitting there thinking "Oh, I guess that hits me."

As for the base building, all the mechanics here are very boring and repetitive. The game does a good job forcing you to interact with each of it's aspects. The base building often forces you to interact with the rogue-like part of the game to get the resources you need. However, this just leads to the game feeling like a chore. As I stated earlier, the combat is very uninspired (Bad Hades if you will) and the base building feels even less so. I often felt like I would unlock things super fast, but never have the resources to keep up with how fast I'd unlock stuff. There was some level of automation in the game, but I felt like the cultists were always terrible at doing their jobs, specifically farming, leading to you needing to do it for them anyways. The day night cycle often left tasks incomplete making it so that progression took much longer than it had any need to, all the while feel like your progression lightning quick with unlocking stuff.

Ultimately, this game is very pretty and has a goofy aesthetic but it's hollow. There is no substance here beyond "Hey imagine if you sacrificed your animal crossing villagers." Go buy Hades if you think the combat looks fun, go buy literally any other base builder if that's what you're looking for.

This game is almost entirely carried by it's aesthetic.

It is an isometric combat rogue-like mixed with a base builder, and it does all of those things at an alright level.

This game excels in nothing other than it's art direction, the combat gameplay is uninteresting. It's not very fun, challenging, or engaging in any way. I found most rooms you can just run through with ease leaving it feeling pretty bland (played on normal difficulty). However, the few times the game did present a challenge I found that the gameplay wasn't sufficient enough for it to feel anything other than unclear hitboxes. The game has a "pop-up" effect on all of it's characters, which often leads to combat in the game feeling very loose and makes it hard to discern where hitboxes are. For 90% of my playthrough this wasn't an issue because the gameplay is so bland and simple that it doesn't matter. But for the 10% of the game that was somewhat difficult, I often didn't feel "challenged" by the difficulty but more often just sitting there thinking "Oh, I guess that hits me."

As for the base building, all the mechanics here are very boring and repetitive. The game does a good job forcing you to interact with each of it's aspects. The base building often forces you to interact with the rogue-like part of the game to get the resources you need. However, this just leads to the game feeling like a chore. As I stated earlier, the combat is very uninspired (Bad Hades if you will) and the base building feels even less so. I often felt like I would unlock things super fast, but never have the resources to keep up with how fast I'd unlock stuff. There was some level of automation in the game, but I felt like the cultists were always terrible at doing their jobs, specifically farming, leading to you needing to do it for them anyways. The day night cycle often left tasks incomplete making it so that progression took much longer than it had any need to, all the while feel like your progression lightning quick with unlocking stuff.

Ultimately, this game is very pretty and has a goofy aesthetic but it's hollow. There is no substance here beyond "Hey imagine if you sacrificed your animal crossing villagers." Go buy Hades if you think the combat looks fun, go buy literally any other base builder if that's what you're looking for.
